summary: The Worst Person in the World is a modern dramedy about the quest for love and meaning in contemporary Oslo. It chronicles four years in the life of Julie (Renate Reinsve), a young woman who navigates the troubled waters of her love life and struggles to find her career path, leading her to take a realistic look at who she really is.

reviews.content: Film divided into several interesting chronicles, with a good direction and a wonderful cast.
A really beautiful film with some stellar acting by the cast all around.

Joachim Trier's directorial debut was dedicated to starting a trilogy that connects through the town he was raised in, sprinkling existential questions about love, ambition, memory and identity. It's just a matter of time till one picture's inclusion of an interconnected slate pops up under the radar, then later discover other works involved and possibly intrigue. His latest caps his connective discourses under evident relativity, relevantly defining a worst trait in a person as titularly stated and narratively explained.

"The Worst Person in the World" is Julie, who lets her indecisiveness constantly change her unclear paths towards a career choice, even desires by her unclear quest for love. Simply put, she's undecided. Divided in fourteen chapters, including a prologue and an epilogue, the film chronicles four years of her life stationed in Oslo as she finds meaning and assurance of who she really is and how to figure out what she truly wants whilst romantically assisted.

Usually a career path is the primary focus that sorts out other crucial choices, while romance provides blissful support that reassures against loneliness. Trier flips it in another direction poised to inspire Julie about how much the self should be valued without any deposition towards the choices she made picks as well. But then the narrative functions like an incoherent romance you lose yourself in, without justifying an uninteresting romance novel you decided to check out only nothing been proven satisfyingly. The chemistries are pure with fine performances enhanced by their thematic interactions, but their romance doesn't stir much regarding indecision as a topic. Though genuinely detracts from the formula, not much is worth engaging in except for the theming that seemingly been demoted as secondary.

Trier's third story of his anthological trilogy based in his hometown "The Worst Person in the World", scores over its thematic communication with performative enriching points, but the romantic focus, albeit the supportive motive, lessens the delivery down to just an average acceptance. (B)

The final instalment of Joachim Trier's ‘Oslo' trilogy has finally arrived. ‘The Worst Person in the World' is a powerful affair that flips the idea of a traditional rom com on its head. Following an indecisive main character who brings you along with her on a 12-chapter quest for to find herself and what she wants from life. ‘The Worst Person in the World' firmly establishes itself as one of 2021's best films right from the get-go.

Julie (Renate Reinsve) is a young woman who finds herself trying to navigate her way through life after a life-changing epiphany which results in her deciding to become a photographer. She first meets Aksel, (Anders Danielsen Lie) a successful comic book artist and the two hit it off, despite Aksel being 15 years her senior. They then enter a relationship together but before long their mundane relationship is interrupted when Julie meets Eivind (Herbet Nordrum), their impromptu meeting results in Julie ending things with Aksel but leaving the chance for them to reconcile. Eivind and Julie soon form their own relationship, quickly forming an ardent bond. What comes next is an emotionally rich journey that forces Julie to take an in-depth look at who she really is.

Renate Reinsve gives an awe-inspiring performance in the lead role, her absence from of the major Best Actress line-ups this awards season is painfully noticeable. Reinsve leads cast that also all give marvellous performances – Anders Danielsen Lie's portrayal of Julie's ex-lover is arguably one of the most gutting things about ‘The Worst Person in the World'. However, the crux of their performances comes when Julie is faced with a major dilemma, turning to Aksel for advice as she faces a tough decision. What follows is an incredibly raw, fragile sequence that tugs at your heartstrings. These wonderful performances allow for Joachim Trier and Eskil Vogt's magnificent screenplay to be brought to the screen.

‘Riders of Justice' cinematographer Kasper Tuxen immerses audiences into the city of Oslo with the help of 35mm film and gorgeous visuals. Tuxen takes full advantage of the Oslo skyline effortlessly integrating it alongside the characters. These easy-on-the-eye visuals are a part of what makes ‘The Worst Person in the World' feel like a masterclass in filmmaking alongside the brilliant screenplay and sensational performances. The film is one of more refreshing features surrounding the 2022 awards season, what it lacks in not being a charming biopic or star-studded action flick, it makes up for in complex characters that audiences can resonate with. It also isn't as clean cut as your typical rom com, Joachim Trier brilliantly bends the rules of the overdone genre, giving it a dark twist that brilliantly works in the film's favour.

Joachim Trier weaves themes of feminism and womanhood into the undertones of ‘The Worst Person in the World', creating an in-depth character study of one woman and her search to find out who she really is, and what kind of person she wants to be. This is a film that forces you as a viewer to investigate yourself and your own relationships – do you see things through to the end or do you give up halfway through? Acclaimed director Joachim Trier brings audiences a film that becomes an instant classic from the first viewing. ‘The Worst Person in the World' is a poignant and mesmerising film that is the perfect way to close Trier's ‘Olso' trilogy, and well-deserving of its two Academy Award nominations.
Characters as real and flawed as you'd meet in real life, with dialogue to match. Beautiful film.
My favourite movie of 2021! Hilarious, romantic, hartbreaking, and with some truly memorable scenes. It's like a romantic comedy if it was made by Bergman.
A modern classic, the best movie of the year with the best performance of the year.

This is actually a foreign film, made in Norway.
 It's set in chapters and yes it's subtitles of course, but the acting is excellent and the plot keeps you interested. Reminds me a bit of an indie film, very new age and simplistic at the same time.  And on top of that, a beautiful last 30 minutes.

This deserves so much more - I cried multiple times throughout, smiled like an idiot, laughed, felt isolated and loveless - Trier and Reinsve ripped out my heart and then, ever so lovingly, placed it back in my chest and stitched me up. I am healing from my wounds and will continue to do so for quite some time.
Just beautiful, everything, every aspects about this movie !
A very well made movie

Excellent film, naturalistic, moving, insightful.  Funny at times but mostly a very real portrayal of what life is like (difficult, alternately confusing and rewarding), what is important, and how much that means.  The acting and dialogue are both extremely realistic and the film is beautifully crafted and paced.  Things can be learned from this and it rises to the level of all great art by transcending expectations while at the same time going just as far as it needs to and not one bit further.  Not for people seeking easy entertainment, but for cinephiles, people who enjoy deep themes and people looking for something thought provoking, and genuinely moving, this is gold.
It all was just far too bleak for me.
Naturalism and whimsy all in one package. Both thoughtful and cinematic.

In a very real way, 'The Worst Person in the World' felt like a mashup of '500 Days of Summer,' 'Take This Waltz,' and 'Rachel Getting Married.' And that's a very good thing.

https://365moviesbyday.bryanbuser.com/the-worst-person-in-the-world/

If I saw this movie like when I was 25 probably I've appreciated it more. Discussed/shown problems and choices do not touch, like from the parallel universe. 
Somehow reminded me of "500 days of Summer".
A bit emotionally heavy and keeps you anxious in a way that's relatable to life

This film didn't feel like watching a movie. It felt chillingly close to the real feelings of getting to know a real person, and the person we get to meet in this film is truly fascinating! A must see film.
excellent and very touching movie

The movie start interesting but it soon become slow-moving and boring. Its feels like that in inspirational driespel they reach to cancer to make women in the odense feel emotional. But what to expect of Norwegian movie. No deep and some cheap nudes and cancer.
This film is about anybody in the same ages of that woman. Despite I am a man, I kind of be mentally sick while watching because sympathizing with that woman was too much for me,

Really lacks crucial narrative and thematic focus. Some simplification during the script-vetting process would have made for a radically more coherent and moving picture. The 2 main leads are wonderful actors and the direction is so tasteful. I'll have to explore this filmmaker's other stuff.

It's hard to imagine a film that better captures the subtle nuances of relationships more effectively than Joachim Trier's The Worst Person in the World.  Renate Reinsve plays Julie, a thirty-something woman who struggles to find her way in life, always in search of a meaningful relationship and seemingly content to toil in a bookshop after having passed on several promising careers.  The film focuses on her relationships with two men, a fiercely intelligent writer of comic books and an amiable barista, successfully delving into remarkable highs and devastating lows, and ultimately ending in tragedy, that evolve over time.  Thanks to Reinsve's sensitive portrayal and an incredibly insightful script from Trier, The Worst Person in the World is a film that is difficult to find fault with.

A really solid drama about life, love, and longevity. It’s well written, acted, and directed. I enjoyed this melancholy movie more than I expected, and the themes and story stuck with me after watching.

The Worst Person in the World (2021): Norway. Not a plot, but a slice of life. Julie changes majors, falls in and out of love, struggles to figure out who she should be in life. Contrary to the title, a normal young woman. Acting so good, the movie feels like cinema verité. A-

This film has quite a fun feel to it, with a fantasy element at play at times. It features some frank sexual discussions but I really liked the scenes depicting the main character, Julie, jogging through the nearby area, while all around appears on pause. It has a slight feel of 'The Secret Life of Walter Mitty' about it, I suppose. Its certainly an intriguing watch of sorts. There are amusing moments, uplifting moments almost and also more sad and even poignant moments too but overall I quite enjoyed this. I thought the characterisation was good. Its about opening up and being true to yourself, to an extent, doing what's right but it's certainly not overly sentimental/saccharine sweet sort of a way. It felt pretty genuine, which I appreciated.

I would recommend this film, yes.
Rare movie that has me thinking to myself that it's a good movie the entire time I'm watching.
It's really good, I would not say its a comedy though.  Original storyline and unique storytelling w/ fantastic and confusing character development.  Just a little sad!
Has some inspired funny parts and some insight in to death and relationships - with the nudity a perfect movie to have watched with the in-laws.

Beautiful and emotional, the worst person in the world is an isolated story of the human experience. It follows one girl as she goes through life in the 20s-40s range of her existence. This story felt real and authentic that was bolstered with a great script. I think a huge impact of the movie for me actually came from the language barrier. Having to read what the characters were saying had a different type of impact on me. I don't know the exact quote but I loved the line where, to sum it up, they talk about memories blurring. Building on that, the final scene and the discussion on death was.. well I'm not really sure what to think about it. I guess it just felt right.
Subtle and bizarre at the same time. Very unique and real in its expression. Smart.
Great acting performance and impactful movie with a really creative script... gets a bit slow though

A film about life, death and the pursuit of happiness in an utterly cerebral and charming form.  Brilliantly, acted and filmed. The drama and understanding of all the tentacles therein may take a while to fire, but the result is like a fine wine.  Renate Reinsve is a revelation in this Norwegian feature.  Final Score: 8.9/10

just not very entertaining story about a women who can't make up her mind about what she wants.
It's very hard to understand how it's generated such buzz. Maybe the critics were paid off?

An original character piece, this story about a girl becoming a woman is smart, touching, bizarre, funny, and moving.  Anchored by a memorable performance, and heavyweight supporting roles.   This creative coming of age indie that is finally, yes finally finding itself again (thanks 20 years of copycat Indies!).  If you liked: Before Sunrise, Run Lola Run, and any vintage Meryl Streep movie.
...Absolutely, Excellent Direction...Overall, Very Well crafted...
TWPITW is a real view of young adulthood. A far from perfect lead character is portrayed wonderfully by Reinsve. It's certainly a love story with a difference. One of the best.

This was good for me.  Many moments portrayed have an authentic human feel with believable human reactions.  I didn't appreciate some "wokeness" in the plot, but that's to be expected these days.  Nonetheless, this was well worth watching for the .99 cents I spent on iTunes to rent it.

I really enjoyed this movie. I found myself becoming very involved in the dialogue and the central characters and felt protective of them all. The scenes with her father altho predictable were also very compelling.

Referred by Norwegian director Joachim Trier as a rom-com for people who hate rom-coms,  this festival circuit darling laments with freewheeling hipness the commitment issues of the millennial crisis through a "coming-of-age" story of a despicably undecided and unfaithful heroine stumbling over romantic and career endeavours.

I was really looking forward to this film, and I thought I would like it a lot more than I did. 

It was interesting enough, and I would have kept watching, but I had a lot of other films at my disposal as I was sitting on an airplane. As it was, I watched the introduction and first three chapters, and I found it interesting enough that I may go back and finish it at some point.

Text: This Norwegian film, The Worst Person in the World, is a romantic comedy that portrays the shattering of human minds, especially in the 20s or 30s of years youths. The protagonist of the movie Julie wants to experience life in her own way but is restricted by some of the personal liabilities in her life. Her mind is getting changed according to her perception of life. She fell in love with many people and as well as she shares a bed with them but for a short span of time she just attracted to a Comic book writer Aksel and they lead a living together life. But at some point, she was just attracted to another man and avoids Aksal but at that time Aksal was so much fond of her and it looks very disappointed for him to leave her. But that relationship with Julie (with Eivind) doesn't was a steady one which also leads to a collapse. So in this sense, the conclusion of the movie relies on the continuing journey of Julie to the next level of her life. She is not affected by the failure in her life because she believes that it all happened to her only because of her own decisions. At the early stage, she always thought about her perspective of life that surrounded her, and that's why she points out that "I feel like a spectator in my own life". She wants to rid of that spectatorship from her life. Is she successful, is the question that remarks the entirety of the movie.
Summary: Success or failure; the question for Julie

This fantastic film speaks honestly about intimate relationships, full of imperfection, deep knowingness, and pain, feelings that are familiar to anyone who has been through a break-up. We journey through life with Julie, a captivating, creative, sometimes selfish but ultimately likeable lead who oscillates constantly between searching and settling. Joachim Trier is skilled at bringing us along for this ride though her internal and external worlds with the help of playful storytelling devices; in one scene, we are treated to a visceral magic mushroom-fuelled Freudian journey through the psyche. In another, time literally stops as the unfolding of a new relationship eclipses all else. In these moments we see inside Julie's mind; Trier wants us to understand his characters and even in moments of sudden upheaval, we understand their motives. The characters are given self-awareness and intelligence, which is part of what makes the film's conflicts so compelling to watch. In one of the most heartbreaking scenes, Julie tells her lover, "I love you and I don't love you" and we are there with her, experiencing her conflict, contradictory but decisive. Humour has a place in the film, too, but to great relief it is never used to break tension; difficult emotions are given time and space to be processed. We are also invited us to think about intergenerational trauma, feminism, ‘wokeness', nostalgia and psychoanalysis, if we want to (these occur through casual dinner party conversations, off-handed comments and a matter-of-fact narrator). We certainly come away from the film with more than we bargained for. We remember that life is messy, unpredictable and wonderful.
Slightly too slow but with great topics ! not presumptuous in its filming, simple, efficient

Always give praise to films that have refreshingly imperfect protagonists. The Worst Person in the World may not be earth-shattering in scope, but it's a testament to the authenticity of the drama that the film can be so impactful with so few characters. 

This Joachim Trier project is particularly hard-hitting given the naturalistic and empathetic development of its conflict, with Renate Reinsve's Julie exhibiting relatable insecurities and uncertainty, which in turn fuels major life-changing events with lasting and profound implications for both herself and those around her. Then there's the film's depiction of love, simultaneously subject to human frailty and potentially resilient beyond measure. Taken together, it's an interesting and potentially devastating taste of life's unpredictability, of connections made and lost through circumstances both beyond and within our control. Even though throwing in a character with a sudden and unexpected terminal disease feels a bit like cheating, there's a core to this film that feels honest and real. 

Solid direction and very good acting, I only wish the trailer didn't spoil the 'frozen time' sequence. (4/5)

The chronicles of four years in the life of Julie (Renate Reinsve), a young woman who navigates the troubled waters of her love life and struggles to find her career path, leading her to take a realistic look at who she really is...

Rotten Tomatoes consensus reads, "The Worst Person in the World concludes Joachim Trier's Oslo Trilogy with a romantic comedy that delightfully subverts the genre's well-worn tropes." The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw described the film as "one of Cannes' best" and "an instant classic". Richard Lawson of Vanity Fair called it "exquisite, wistful (and downright sad)", praising the cast performances and Trier's writing. In his review for IndieWire, David Ehrlich gave the film a grade of B and commended Reinsve's performance, stating "If Julie is less of a character than a vividly realized archetype, Reinsve didn't get the message." Vanity Fair and The Atlantic declared The Worst Person in the World to be the best film of 2021.

This is Joachim Trier´s third film in his "Oslo Trilogy", following "Reprise" (2006) and "Oslo, August 31st" (2011). The film premiered in competition at the 2021 Cannes Film Festival to widespread critical acclaim, with Renate Reinsve winning the award for Best Actress for her performance in the film. At the 94th Academy Awards, the film was nominated for Best International Feature Film and Best Original Screenplay. (via Wikipedia) The film has a prologue, 12 chapters and a epilogue. As a fan of Joachim Trier´s "Reprise" and specifically "Oslo, August 31st" I was glad to see that he finally was closing the "Oslo Trilogy" with "The Worst Person in the World" and reading about all the accolades and praise I was really looking forward to see it. First of all, the acting is of a very high standard and Renate Reinsve gives us a splendid performance. And Anders Danielsen Lie is great as always. The story is hardly unique and I personally thought that the film is a bit scattered with all the chapters that creates an unbalance. Maybe that was Trier´s aim as Julie´s life is scattered. However, that is an issue to my mind since the flow becomes broken. I think as well that that the film is a bit flatlined, there´s no emotional punch like in "Oslo, August 31st" which I miss at least. I can relate to Julie in certain of her actions, but is she likeable? Not really, which makes you less engaged. And that goes for Aksel as well. I had high hopes and they were not fully met. It´s a solid film, but not Trier´s best in my book.
Irritating characters in a terminally uninsteresting  and unfunny movie about everyday life as a Millenial. I have had more interesting walks.
Wonderful movie, beautifully shot and with great characters. I loved the location aesthetics and wardrobe for the main character in particular. Beautiful movie.
The film is about finding one's self in the worst of times, it's amazing.

I understand this may not be the kind of movie some like (see the 1-star reviews), but it’s definitely “my kind of movie”. And what a movie! Definitely my favorite performance of the year. It hit all the notes I relate to. If you like movies like “Frances Ha”, “Blue is the Warmest Color”, or “Annie Hall”, then you should like this one. If not, then avoid (then you won’t be angry like the people who didn’t like it).
Terrific cast.  Compelling story.   Love Renate Reinsve, Well executed.
This fucking movie is refreshing as fuck. Reminded me of REAL GODDAMN FUCKING LIFE. Felt nearly every scene as if it were a memory in my own life. Fuck every other movie right now.
good story on a relationship. she is the name of the movie, good acting.

An incredibly moving story in which one immerses themselves in the meandring emotions of the main character. The instability in her education path, relationships, proffesions or living situation is deeply modern and very topical, being the source of suffering, but at the same time of unquestioned freedom.
Saw myself reflected in several aspects of this movie. Loved the chapter structure and the performances.
Great actress in the lead and a really well-told struggles of being a woman in her late 20s/early 30s.

A true stunner. This is the best film I've seen since Chloe Zhao's THE RIDER (which may or may not tell you something about my taste in films). Beautifully written, magnificently performed. I cannot recommend it highly enough.
Feels slow in parts but there are moments where everything comes together and makes sense. Makes you think for days after watching.
Boring...boring...boring..tedious/annoying characters talking too much

I took a look at the reviews before I went to see the movie. I did not enjoy this movie at all. I thought it was boring, I found no connection with the lead character, I really don't know what people saw in this movie, nor did my companion. We both agreed it was a waste of our time.

It's good, not quite up to the level of the hype.
The lead actress is great, so are the supporting men. Although I never  quite bought their relationships or that she would even be attracted to them.
The main issue, for me was that it just seemed kind of a mess of ideas and styles. It seemed like a string of events...as if the writer thought, ..."and then this happened..and oh wait...what if this happened?". It never quite cohered.

The dark and difficult existential questions that plague us all are tackled with refreshing honesty in this stunningly shot film of the year contender.

Touching upon themes of identity, love, and ambition, the film is an important reminder that the paralysing internal crises we face in adulthood are neither unique nor special, but the unavoidable consequences of living.

Infectiously sweet and romantic at times, and unapologetically wistful at others, The Worst Person In The World presents life not as we'd like it, but as it really is.
Work of art, so touching and real.

The Worst Person in the World by Joachim Trier is easily one of the best films in recent years & a memorising work of perfection.
Broken up in 12 chapters, The Worst Person in the World takes you on the a journey of Julie's life, a young woman who battles her own indecisiveness as she traverses the troubled waters of her love & struggles to find her career path.
Beautifully filmed & a wonderful performance from Renate Reinsve.

Loved it! Usually hate films longer than 90 – 100 minutes but the 2 hours plus just flew by. The protagonist becomes more endearing as the film progresses. Was sucker-punched by the unexpected twist/story development (no spoilers) which is always good in a film. Felt very emotional leaving the cinema, reflecting on past relationships. Plus on a totally superficial level it's always good to spend time in Oslo apartments on screen…they're so effortlessly cool!
Couldn’t get through it. The main character lives up to its title. She’s so unlikeable I couldn’t finish this film.
It was very well done!!
This is the worst movie in the world.
Thoughtful movie lots of things to think about afterwards. Some of the graphic scenes were unnecessary.

Renate Reinsve is wonderful, and there are so many well put-together scenes -- and yet, the story is ruined by the fact that it's a lie. 

Ostensibly about a woman coming of age in her twenties, "The Worst" is actually not about a woman at all. This is a fantasy by two men about two men who are redeemed by the love of a woman who has no life outside of her relationships with them. "The worst person" of the title is the first of these men, a somewhat sexist gen-x artist who takes her for granted, and then, apparently is redeemed in her eyes by getting terminal cancer and telling her she was the best thing to ever happen to him. Reinsve's character is not a person, she is a device designed to make the film appear less sexist.

It's such a shame, because so much of the film is really beautiful. At it's core, however, it's a guy at the dinner party who's coached his radiant, younger girlfriend to agree that men just can't "express" themselves like they could before #metoo. Sure, it's compelling when she says it, but did you ever consider that she might have her own opinion to express, Joe?

From the outset you think that this might be a snarky anti-romantic comedy that's drenched in smug irony but as it goes along the movie reveals itself to be a deeply emotional examination of how people fall in and out of love and the regrets that haunt us.

I loved this film. If you are a wandering Millennial, you will probably relate to this but the story morphs into a much more universal theme so I would recommend this to a wide audience. Beautifully crafted, moving, and immensely entertaining. I laughed almost as much as I cried.

In Joachim Trier's Oscar-nominated film, Renate Reinsve's Julie's romantic liasions over a period of 4 years are chronicled and explored in 12 chapters with a prologue and an epilogue like a novel, accompanied by her character's deadpan-ish voiceover, and in lesser hands, this can come across as gimmicky and smug. Instead, what we get is a charming female-centric film, which considering it's co-written by two men, Trier & Eskil Vogt, happily doesn't feel awkward or disingenuous. There's certainly notes of early Woody Allen/Annie Hall here, before it moves subtly into Greta Gerwig/Noah Baumbach territory (Marriage Story and Frances Ha come to my mind), especially when romance is replaced with the cold hard facts of co-habitation. Which makes the final act dip into melodrama and Love Story territory a little hard to fathom and tonally slightly jarring. However, what holds everything beautifully together is, firstly, Trier's flair as an imaginative film-maker. Everyone who watches this will find that scene with a city of people frozen mid-action a romantically delightful moment, which also turns out to be the turning point of the film, but there are other smaller moments (like the hallucination sequence or an air-drumming scene in hospital) to cherish and makes me appreciate what a meticulous and visually fascinating director Trier is. Secondly, and equally important, are the tremendous performances, by Anders Danielsen Lie, who's very good even if he has sympathy on his side for his tender portrayal of Askel; and Reinsve who's spectacular, making an otherwise irritating character, understandable and almost loveable despite her flaws. Calling this an anti-romcom just because it's about a young woman going in and out of relationships seems doing this a disservice. For me, it's a story about someone who grew up and found herself who just happens to be female, for a change.
Very watchable; an interesting character study.
Absolutely brilliant. Amazing directing and acting. Heartbreaking but life affirming. Probably my favourite film of the year

Oscar nominee for foreign language film and original screenplay where we follow a young woman through her meandering life and relationships... I assume she is supposed to be the "worst person in the world" since she treats both of her love interests pretty badly..  The actress is pretty good and the film has some things to say about relationships but it didn't really grab me like it could have.
...Excellent Direction...About A Messed Up 30 Yr. Female...I Found The Movie Quite Depressing...

Probably my favourite film of the year! Such a heartbreaking film about my generation, about our woes and our fatal flaws, about our willingness to connect and our inability to commit. And even though it's a film that openly states its purpose to portray a generation on screen, it's so deliciously personal and intimate, with two actors at its core who are doing absolutely brilliant work. I'd like to single out Anders Danielsen Lie, who is also in another 2021 release I love. He's such a lyrical, almost unreal presence in this movie. I don't know how he and the director Joachim Trier pulled this character off without going sentimental and making the character's dramatic purpose obvious.  One thing though: I didn't need this epilogue. I think the film would have benefitted from an ending with her walking the streets of Oslo at night and then welcoming the sun. A chapter in her life has ended, and she might feel mature enough to make some real choices. I think this would have worked better. Showing us her reality five years later, or a year later, only lessens the impact.

One of the best indies of 2021. It has a little bit of everything (comedy, drama) but in the most touching ways and has so much to offer that it doesn't mind giving all along. 
It starts pretty funny with a great sense of rhythm and a clever sense of writing and embarks you on a thrillin ride through love and life. The drama part may appear a little more slow but is that essential to the character's journey that you'll find yourself bursting into tears even before realizing that you watched a great movie. By the way the cast is top notch, can't wait to see the lead actress in more crowd pleasing films. The direction is also inventive and effective. A must see and deeply enjoyable.

I actually went to the theater in NYC to see this film but just didn't get all the hype. I love foreign films but thought this was was incredibly boring until it finally got to a certain incident. It was basic screenwriting 101 and left me feeling disappointed.
I really liked this movie. Was hoping for a happy ending, but that’s probably why it’s a good movie. Not predictable

I’m amazed at this film, how pleasurable and how painful it is. It’s almost unbearable that I will never know Julie’s life before she steps into this brilliant film, nor two hours later after she steps out. If I only had a little more time, and a little more still. But that’s the ache we all feel knowing our time with loved ones will end.
Not a fan of long and depressing

Was not expecting much but I was pleasantly drawn in deeper minute-by-minute. It's a surprisingly hard hitting narrative that you do not see coming but somehow gets right to the most intimate parts of you. It feels so very human. Is easily now one of my favorites.
Such an overrated bore.
Fine plot, good acting, but overly long.  Much more of it needed to land on the cutting room floor.  I ran out of patience after about 90 minutes.

Perfection - this movie took an unabashed approach to examining the hardest parts of life, while sprinkling in some truly laugh-out-loud moments. The story was masterfully told and the acting was impeccable. A profound and powerful narrative, it's a must see.
maybe my new favourite film - reflective of a woman's life in such a calm but painful way. fleabag but better. sat through the whole credits and cried my eyes out

The Worst Person in the World (Norwegian: Verdens verste menneske) is a 2021 dark romantic comedy-drama film directed by Joachim Trier 💔 

Awesome! 😀
I'd totally recommend it 👍🏼👍🏼
One of my favourite movies of the year ⭐️

such a quiet meditation on being a young adult, but instead of focusing on the listlessness of your early twenties, trier instead focuses on something so much scarier: nearing thirty and having no idea what you want to do, who you are outside of your relationships, and what you might contribute to your life and those around you. absolutely beautiful, with some stunning shots, beautiful cinematography, and fantastic acting from all the lead.

This one ranks right up there, for me, with "Leaving Las Vegas" as extremely well-done films that demand to be seen, but definitely only once.  It left me feeling depressed in the end.

By the way, as that last line might suggest, this is not really a romantic comedy as some are calling it.  More like a heavy drama with a fair number of light moments.
A very funny romantic movie that will put a smile on your face. It was a beautiful movie that a lot of people will be able to relate to and enjoy.

A delightful portrait of a 30-something woman trying to figure out her place in the world and in her own love life. When she crashes a wedding and meets an alluring stranger, her life begins to change in ways she didn't expect, and perhaps didn't want. Oscar Nominated for Best International Feature and Writing (Original Screenplay).

How is this a "masterpiece"? It's decent, but absolutely overrated. And I'm in the "target demographic". Much better nordic movies and tv shows depicting modern life and struggles out there. The music is good.
Above avg Indyscript & actingwell donehuman condition love story of self and relationshipsloved it
I couldn't care less about the movie or the lead character. Walked out of the theater halfway through. I can't believe this movie has a 97% on rotten tomatoes.

Quite refreshing movie, people with real problems. If you read what the movie about, it might not seem interesting, but this movie makes you stick to your screen. You are engaged with the characters, feel and understand what they are going through. Great real life drama movie.
It was a descent movie, but it took quite awhile to get to the meat & potatoes of the main characters. Great acing and beautiful cinematography.
I absolutely loved this movie! It’s a reflection of a real life. It’s somber, happy, exciting and mundane all at the same time.

terrific film. Well deserving of it's International film Oscar nomination. More character study, light on the plot. Three main leads are all very good. At first I thought it was going to be a Norwegian Woody Allen movie without the laughs, but no. A very interesting dive into the life of a woman about to turn 30, who knows where she wants to go with her life, but has taken a meandering path to get there - told through her love life, family life and inner life. Fascinating. Mesmerizing. Enlightening.

I think artistic expression resonates even stronger when I read stories or watch films from other countries, or created in totally different time periods, that dig into themes and emotions so recognizable to, and in, myself. I am always left in awe at how universal and timeless certain aspects of the human experience appear to be, making it impossible not to feel, and maybe even bask or revel in, this deeper connection we share as a species.

This was a film I knew very little about going in but surely will stick with me for quite awhile after. I could definitely find a way to relate to most of the characters, who all came across as uniquely interesting and well developed, and I thought the performances were excellent all around. The dialogue between these characters was probably most important to the film's success, and felt incredibly authentic, easily capturing my attention and focus, allowing me to feel at times like I was in the actual room. I definitely was getting some "Before..." trilogy vibes at times and even though the films were still quite different in many ways, I remember being left with some of the same emotions during the credits.

And sometimes, similar to Julie, it can be a stronger experience just to feel things, without having to try to frame every emotion through words.

*2022 Theater #6
Imo overrated. Some good acting but I could have missed it and been ok.

Drifting through life.  So this shows the late twenties/early thirties in the life of Julie (Renate Reinsve).  She doesn't quite know what she wants to do as a career, so she goes in and out of education and professions.  She also doesn't know what she wants from a partner, so she bails on relationships when things get difficult.  This movie focuses on two of her main relationships, one with Aksel (Anders Danielsen Lie), and one with Eivind (Herbert Nordrum).  Now other than the Oscar buzz surrounding this, it was the title that grabbed me with this one.  It just reaches out and gets your attention immediately, so I knew I had to check this out even without knowing a ton about it.  I think this works better for home viewing than in a theater, but I did ultimately end up liking it.  Now I'm sure I'm not alone when I say that I expected this woman to be a worse person.  Yes, she can be selfish from time to time, but it is still relatable to be unsure if you're in the right line of work or with the person you're supposed to be with for the rest of your life.  It's the weight of expectations put on by yourself that can make you feel like the worst person in the world.  Julie is a flawed person, and this is very much a character study, so I can see people having a disconnect if they are looking for something to latch onto.  For me, that wasn't a bother, and I liked the poignant moments that get peppered throughout.  This is a very existential movie, and I found it similar to the beloved-by-everyone-but-not-by-me Drive My Car, only I found this script to be more relatable.  Because it gets contemplative at times, I did feel the length, which gets exacerbated by the fact that this is divvied up into fourteen chapters and tells you as such at the start.  It made me check the clock when I didn't even want to, which is why I think this would work better to watch this when it hits streaming.  That way, you can watch 3-4 chapters and take a small break as you would do with an engaging miniseries.  The Worst Person in the World is a smaller and quieter story, but I did always relate even when my attention wavered.  They always bring it back home with a good point or a striking line of dialogue, which is what I appreciated most about this film.  I also highly enjoyed the moments of magical realism that they slip into; you can see it in the trailer, and it makes you wish that was more prevalent.  Overall, I can give this a low recommendation.

I've never seen a movie that I love so much but also makes me feel so… mellow?

It has its really sad beats and basically prays on every anxiety of mine as a person trying to make decisions about life but has a nice like, "it will work out" type message at the center of it. So many interesting parallels about taking things from the past parts of our lives and using them to better us as people and discover ourselves as we grow into adulthood. Just because an event happened and it's in the past doesn't mean you can ignore it, even if you REALLY want to.

It's kinda an adult coming of age story that is also just an absolute joy at times. Love love love!
One of the best films that I have seen in the past 5 years!
boring and tedious couldnt care less about this millenial and her problems. walked out midway
Movie not for everyone. There is nudity, sex scenes, & drug  experimentation. However, beyond that is a well-written & delivery of an adult coming of age with relationships & career.

"The Worst Person in the World" is an effective film because it truly feels like a breath of fresh air in the romance genre. I liked how the story was presented and I thought it felt unpredictable at every turn. The main character in this movie is very impulsive and constantly changing her mind about things, and that kept me engaged throughout. I think it is a very unique character study and tackles modern relationships in an honest and human way. I also think the lead actress in this movie does an exceptional job and creates a complex character with her performance. Overall, this is a human story with many interesting topics and a solid presentation of its storylines and characters.
Plot unwraps slowly but keeps your interest and the acting is uniformly excellent
nice film slow paced. wouldn't watch it again. the relationships between the characters were touching and genuine. but I had to fight to stay awake.
The acting was superb, it did keep my interest, but it was just OK for me. You may love it- a lot of people do, apparently. Go see for yourself.
Great story of a 30 year old woman that goes through a couple of relationships trying to find herself. It's not often that women take the lead in movies so this was a nice surprise.

This is an excellent movie. My only problem with it has nothing to do with the movie itself - well acted, well written, and so on. The problem I have is I'm not the target audience. If I were in my 20's or 30's, I'd be on the edge of my seat with its themes of insecurity, relationships, family issues, and so on. My problem is I'm 72 years old, and for me,  all those issues were half a century ago. This was a bit of a trip down a memory lane I'd rather forget. If you're my age, you can probably skip this film. If younger, go and see it.
It was excellent and very moving.  The actors were superb!   The musical score was also very good.  Definitely a best picture nominee.
I loved this movie so much. I love how strong and vulnerable they made the main female character. I may go back and see it again

MOVIE REVIEW
The Worst Person in the World (Verdens verste menneske)
5 out of 5 stars

Genre: Comedy, Drama, Romance
Year Released: 2021
Rating: R
Runtime: 2h 8m
Director: Joachim Trier
Writer: Joachim Trier, Eskil Vogt
Cast: Renate Reinsve, Anders Danielsen Lie, Herbert Nordrum
Where To Watch: In select theaters now

"Once you overcome the one-inch tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films." - Bong Joon-ho, easily one of my favorite quotes. There was a time that I wouldn't watch anything with subtitles. Thankfully I was given multiple opportunities to overcome this bias and have, in return, seen so many films that I would never have seen otherwise.

I don't hand out five-star reviews regularly; they're reserved for indeed what are my favorite films each year. To put it in perspective, the only other film I gave five stars to this past year was "Last Night in Soho." Cinema is personal, and I don't know what makes one better than the next to each person; no one does. My favorite films from last year maybe someone else's least favorites. That's fine; if we all liked the same movies, the world would be a pretty dull place.

This film defines why I do the Oscar Death Race each year. I know that not everyone is a big fan of the Oscars (I currently have a pretty big issue with them handing out what they consider lesser awards before the ceremony, but that's a topic for another post.) You don't have to be the biggest fan of The Academy to appreciate still the films that get nominated. Each year I get to watch so many notable movies, I've been on the hunt for this one for a while now, and I was ecstatic when I saw that it was being released at a theater local to me.

Renate Reinsve (Julie), the lead of the film, and the glue that holds it together give what I would consider one of the year's best performances. The fact she wasn't nominated for best actress blows my mind. I will say that The Academy has made some significant strides this year, getting international films nominated in multiple categories (especially with this and "Drive My Car.") Reinsve was able to capture my imagination precisely by giving a realistic performance. I felt like I was almost watching a documentary rather than an acting performance. It should go without saying that a lot of this appreciation indeed goes to the writers and director.

The other two most vital roles in the film were Anders Danielsen Lie (Aksel) and Herbert Nordrum (Eivind), who played critical roles that worked together to complete the story. I was shocked how both were able to go from villains to heroes in my eyes throughout the film. The film is beautifully broken into 12 parts (as well as a prologue and epilogue) with a runtime of just a little over two hours; it makes the entire movie very digestible to any audience.

As I've covered before, I'm not a massive fan of films that are artsy just because, thankfully, we see a grounded approach to the imagination here. A few scenes are "beyond belief" but are given reasons as to why. They're not just fantastical without purpose; I have a much higher level of appreciation when there are intentional decisions to film. This allows a film that's based in reality but one that lets your imagination wander.

The only ironic aspect of the film I found odd was that Oslo (the city the film primarily took place) is the largest city in Norway; however, Julie repeatedly runs into people she knows. I rarely run into people I know, and I live in a much smaller city. It was just an amusing little bit I picked up on.

For more reviews and my YouTube channel, please visit linktr.ee/Overlyhonestmoviereviews

Follow me on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube. Find my social media accounts on most platforms simply by searching Overly Honest Movie Reviews.

I'm always happy to hear from my readers; please say hi or send me any questions about all things movies.

I rarely use the M word, but I really think this film might be a masterpiece. This movie truly spoke to me as a millennial. To say this film is perceptive doesn't even begin to describe the magic this film gifts the viewer. I was totally entranced from start to finish. See this in a theater if you possibly can. You truly will be moved.

While I appreciate the idea of a film that follows an indecisive and passive character ("the worst person in the world", Julie), I found this film to be extremely meandering and confusing. Ultimately, we are to understand that Julie ends up in a better place (she's a single, confident, photographer now!), I really felt like her transition happened only in the last five minutes. A lot is said about having not likable characters, but I just didn't like Julie and I found most of the characters pretty detestable. I'm really not sure what people are talking about when they said that this movie is redefining rom-coms. Maybe seek out 500 Days of Summer for a rom-com subversion movie instead.
So original. Great Screenplay.
Is the title just a bad translation? It's not the worse movie this year, nor is it the best.
The storyline was emotionally engaging, quirky and perfectly sets up the surprise ending.

An okayish exploration of teenage in the lives of Norwegian people. The performances, acting, directing, dialogues and cinematography were good, but nothing extraordinary than your average romance except for beautiful background of Oslo, Norway.

This is my 28th film of the festival and easily my favorite. I definitely pushed myself too far this festival and hit a wall, and staying at the worst airbnb imaginable where I could only get two hours of sleep didn’t help. I spent most of the morning being fucking miserable and just trying to stay awake. Then this movie started and I had goosebumps from the first frame to it’s last. I felt invigorated for every minute of it’s 2 hour runtime and just sat there with a dumb smile on my face even during the film’s most painful moments because I knew I was watching something that would mean a lot to me for years to come.

I don’t have any analysis rn, I’m just happy when a movie can make me feel this way. Oslo, August 31st was one of my favorite films of the 2010s and somehow Joachim Trier has crafted something at a completely different register but every bit it’s equal. This is easily my favorite film of the festival, it’s gonna be near impossible to beat as my film of the year. Movies rule, man.

EDIT: 

Alright, it’s been 2 days so I’ll expand a bit. If you follow the work of Joachim Trier, since his 2006 debut, Reprise through 2012’s Oslo, August 31st, and finally this film he’s been creating a very loose trilogy defined more by themes, location, and actors than by some overarching narrative. And the stories he’s been telling have simply been these kind of very true to life films about young people trying to find their way in the world and more specifically in the city of his native Oslo. He’s had a real knack for capturing the kind of experience of being a millenial better than probably any filmmaker I can think of and has done so with a real empathy and humanity. Sometimes those portraits of life can be really bleak like his prior film Oslo, August 31st but they all feature moments of breathtaking beauty and this is perhaps his warmest and most beautiful yet. 

It features all the ideas essential to his work of identity, nostalgia, love, ambition, and interpersonal relationships with as much care as his work ever has, but with his age, he seems to now have enough distance to both be wiser in his observations and find the inherent comedy in the concerns that seem to dominate our lives in the moment. In this one it centers around Julie, a young woman who having just turned 30 finds herself still unsure of her place in the world, unable to find reassurance in her professional or personal life of where she’s going. And as we see the next few years of her life the film doesn’t cop out and provide easy answers but ends with a resolution that I found completely beautiful and extremely touching.

Idk, I’m still on a high from this one, I’ve sat here for two days now just listening to the soundtrack on repeat desperately googling for a release date so I can see it again.

As of now, this is my first 5 star film of the decade.

I don't understand where all the positive reviews are coming from.  This movie just seems OK.  Really nothing special about it.  A standard movie about dating and relationships.  I feel like I have seen this same movie many times before and this doesn't bring anything new or unique.  Nothing really bad about it.. and if dating/relationship movies are your thing.. this will probably be fine.  Just nothing special and not really worth the time to go out to the theater on this one.
Small story told with kindness and perception

I am a true cinemaphile who happens to admire and learn many things from different cultures in foreign films. This film brings to mind other scandinavian filmmakers of the past.  The starkness of the lives at a point of interruption with emotional purging is the core of this film that is made of a continum of vignettes.  It is book-like, the chapters are a forward and backward glance int o the characters and their private worlds and how they journey through them.  I highly recommend this film as it keeps you going where some others have not had that forward thrust to finding the ideal life.  There is no ideal life, just the skeletal frame upon which man creates his own stories and truths. Like Ibsen, we become more aware of the needs of a female in today's world, which like Ibsen, who broke barriers of the femal strength and breaking away from what is supposed to be the normal, we are taken step by step into a plot that swerves and then is accomplished.  This is a wonderful story of sexual admissions and omissions.
This was a really good coming-of-age love story.
I loved this movie. Dark, funny, quirky & uncomfortable at times - but it dealt with real & raw emotions, and hooked me from the very beginning

A shallow film about a shallow person. I hoped there'd be a point at first, then resigned myself to just enduring the 2 hours. Every character in the film was more interesting than the main one. If the lead actress weren't pretty no one would care at all. Plenty of shots of people walking and dancing, trying to fill time for such a paltry story.
no plot.  slice of life.  only saved by good acting.

I was surprised that this movie effected me so deeply. Most of the reviews described the film as" a coming of age" film, but it was much more than that to me. It was about love, loss, living with the difficult choices one makes in one's life, acknowledging love, facing death, and learning from the mistakes one makes in life. The film had a universal humanity that spoke of all of the complexities of life. The performances were spot on and the narrative flowed seamlessly even though the film had "chapters". I walked away feeling so glad to have seen this film. It acknowledged many of the emotions of life in a natural,  organic way.

This is the lutefisk of film, we are told it is a Norwegian delicacy so we all politely don't acknowledge it is a plate of rotting fish.  

This movie was a vapid, pointless, trite affair wrapped in empty style.  The main protagonist is merely an underdeveloped sketch of an actual character.  She's an indecisive young Norwegian woman who we are told has above-average intelligence and beauty but works at a book store.  Apparently, she is a great writer also because she likes to write about having sexual experiences with flaccid men.  In its greatest sin, the movie predictably stumbles into themes of life and death at the end, but fate interferes with her having to make an actual choice.  It is as if the director didn't want the young ingenue ruined by any actual characterization.  

Do not see this boogie meandering garbage  - it will only make you lose faith in the film criticism community and doubt your own sanity.  To be fair, there is one scene that resonated with me, a dream sequence where the lead flung a tampon at her father's face.  This movie is the tampon flung at all our faces.

Joachim Trier's Oslo-trilogy comes to an end in its third decade. In Reprise (2006), Oslo, August 31st (2011) and The Worst Person in the World (2021) all tell different stories that focus primarily on interpersonal relationships and study them with great attention to detail. In the case of this black-humoured romance, the focus is on the inner life of the protagonist Julie, who over the course of four years increasingly asks herself questions of meaning about her own existence and the relationships with her fellow human beings.

While the Norwegian capital is the setting for the events in the trilogy of the same name, Anders Danielsen Lie is the other constant in Trier's unrelated three-parter. In all the films he plays an essential role and is directly involved in the central relationships. Here he is Julie's distinctly older boyfriend, Aksel. An artist who devotes his entire career to a children's comic series with a cat as the title character, giving free rein to his artistic vision. His character is initially established as merely Julie's better half, but transforms as he progresses until he suddenly becomes controversial. If it weren't for Lie's charismatic performance, Aksel would even be despicable and unlikable. However, you never think of him that way because there is so much more slumbering in this person than the abstracted artist. Watching him play with mimicry and emotion breaks your heart and makes it beat faster at other moments. Foremost responsible for this is the chemistry Lie shares with his scene partner Renate Reinsve. Reinsve is the true revelation as the internally torn Julie. Although her decisions often leave you shaking your head, I could completely relate to her in every situation. Because Julie does what most people in ambivalent relationships completely forget to do: She listens to herself. She is a self-determined person who makes decisions only out of her own intention. This either means that you can never really relate to this character and take her to your heart or, as in my case, you find her totally relatable. Perhaps this was also the reason why I always emotionally enjoyed putting myself in Julie's head and followed her every move with great interest.

The grandiose acting would never have such an imposing effect without an equally strong screenplay. Joachim Trier has understood how to write and direct this story as real as possible. This is not only due to insanely authentic dialogue (The break-up scene!), but also to the way he brings certain narrative strands together. What some interpret as poorly structured is, for me, very organically woven together. I realise that the division into chapters in films bothers a lot of people. In The Worst Person in the World, however, they help me to stay fully engaged with the characters and their developments. The chronology of the script makes the film feel very down to earth and not at all pretentious. In the end, The Worst Person in the World is an unassuming romance that, like so many films in this genre, doesn't try to explain relationships with a raised finger, but simply lets them happen - and I credit Joachim Trier for that.
More honest about what it is like to grow up than I am willing to be.

The worst person in the world? Hardly.  But, the film manages to breath life into a complex and at times baffling character in this Norwegian gem.   Renate Reinsve plays Julie.  When we first meet her she is a medical student.  She isn't fully engaged to her studies, so she drops out to pursue psychology.  She starts dating one of her professors and moves onto wanting to be a photographer.  She shifts again when she starts dating a Aksel, a comic book artist several years older than she.   The film is romantic and at times a comedy, but it is not a romantic comedy. The characters and situations are far too complex and thought provoking.  Julies biggest crime is believing that excitement comes in trying something new.  The beginning is better than the routine. The beauty off the film comes in watching her mature to a point when she recognizes that the true rewards come with time and are not easily earned.  And that life isn't about setting reset when the thrill of the chase is done.
This should be names the worst movie in the world or at least the most boring. 2 hours of my life, wasted.
It was a beautiful movie. Natural, real and really captivating. The acting was amazing.

Amazing story, it never lulls you! Even subtitles work!
The cast is excellent and Renate Reinsve is totally captivating in her role and absolutely gorgeous!
Very tender and a bit brutal in all the best ways.

This is, perhaps, a perfect movie. It's meandering while retaining a clear narrative structure, anchored by an absolutely magnificent performance by Renate Reinsve as Julie. I can't wait to watch this again, and again, and again. An instant classic.
